Prerequisites: ACG2071 AND MAC2233 (OR EQUIVALENT OR HIGHER)
Course Description: THIS COURSE IS THE FIRST OF A THREE-COURSE SEQUENCE ON THE THEORY AND APPLICATIONS OF THE ACCOUNTING PROCESS, STANDARDS, AND REGULATIONS. THE FOCUS IS ON THE EVALUATION OF THE ACCOUNTING CYCLE AND THE ASSET ACCOUNTS. TOPICS INCLUDE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS, ACCOUNTING INFORMATION SYSTEMS, TIME VALUE OF MONEY, AND CURRENT ASSETS.
Objectives / Learning Outcome(s) / Major:
1.	DESCRIBE THE ACCOUNTING ENVIRONMENT AND THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF FINANCIAL REPORTING.
2.	APPLY GENERALLY ACCEPTED ACCOUNTING PRINCIPLES (GAAP) TO THE ACCOUNTING CYCLE INCLUDING THE PREPARATION OF FINANCIAL STATEMENTS.
3.	USE TECHNOLOGY TO INTERPRET, ANALYZE AND GENERATE QUANTITATIVE DATA PERTAINING TO VARIOUS ACCOUNTS WITH A PARTICULAR EMPHASIS ON ASSET ACCOUNTS.
4.	DIFFERENTIATE BETWEEN U.S. GAAP AND INTERNATIONAL FINANCIAL REPORTING STANDARDS (IFRS). 
5.	EVALUATE THE LIQUIDITY, EFFICIENCY, AND PROFITABILITY OF AN ORGANIZATION THROUGH FINANCIAL RATIO ANALYSIS TECHNIQUES.
Transfer Status: GUARANTEED TRANSFER TO INSTITUTION OFFERING SAME COURSE.
